channel.title: Deob bans
channel.description:
Well, deobs bans. What are the reason? Is it a trap? If it is a trap, is this trap known?
If you know why and what, please post a exsample of how to remove this trap.
Thanks! ~zen

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @zenteo zenteo
item.description:
@zenteo wrote:

Thanks

Read full topic

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Make an interface called Player and compile in the normal way:

interface Player { public int getX(); public int getY(); }
Then load the corresponding player class in the client. Add the Player interface. Add the getX and getY methods so they do something like this:

public int getX() { return ab.d; }
That is, just return a single field.
Then you can do this: (where getPlayer is another get method you have added.

client cl = new client(); Player p = (Player)cl.getPlayer(); int xLocation = p.getX();

Read full topic

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @zenteo zenteo
item.description:
@zenteo wrote:

Exception:

Yes, updating a bot using BCEL. If you put in some time, it’s not that hard to understand BCEL/bytecode etc.

So I need to make a “interface” or something in Java and add the funtions that returns the un-Deobed clients functions/methodes?
I know that the class-file has the structure of the classes/functions/methodes, but the methodes/functions are written in bytecode : ASM like code.
The classes doesn`t have the “real” names of the classes/other stuffs, so how do the updaters know what name the stuff should have?
the exsample of an “interface!”:

Function GetX()
{
return px.c()
}

Is this the right way?
I dunno what BCEL have to do with this…
I shall google a lot more now

Read full topic

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

_cake:

Please, I know your learning, but don’t pretend you know a lot of it.

OK, I’m sorry. I am absolutely dismal at BCEL, and have no recollection of saying I was ever any good at using BCEL or Java programming in general. If that is what I was implying with that post, it was unintentional.

Read full topic

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @zenteo zenteo
item.description:
@zenteo wrote:

BAsh(CntLgn):

It is possible to write code around counter/traps but it is easier to just use a non-deobed client and just add some methods returning interesting fields.

Is that the build/updater stuffs?
Because I can`t use them -.-

Read full topic

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

[quote=“zenteo, post:3, topic:157603”]Isn`t it possible to write in manipulations of those counts/other raports?
And remove/change the trap snippets?
Are all of those traps known?
Is it new traps for each update?[/quote]
It is possible to write code around counter/traps but it is easier to just use a non-deobed client and just add some methods returning interesting fields. I don’t think many of the traps are known as very few people appear to have a working bot or a heavily renamed deob. I’m not sure if they add new traps every update, but they certainly add them and probably more frequently when there is a known bot.

Read full topic

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @Hyjall Hyjall
item.description:
@Hyjall wrote:

[quote=“zenteo, post:3, topic:157603”]Isn`t it possible to write in manipulations of those counts/other raports?
And remove/change the trap snippets?
Are all of those traps known?
Is it new traps for each update?[/quote]

1-It is possible, however how would we know how many method counts would be legal?
2-Removing trap snippets wouldn’t be the best idea, because if the client is missing for example a methodCounter then that would be reason for a ban too.
3-You can’t be sure if all traps are known.
4-We don’t know.

Read full topic

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @zenteo zenteo
item.description:

item.title: Deob bans
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

Yes, it is a trap, Jagex has method counters, which essentially count the number of times a method is called, and report it to the server. There is also the fact your not running it in a web page, and the jar isn’t signed.
And now, over to semaphore for the other million and one reasons deobfuscated clients are detectable and how to avoid being detected.

Read full topic
